content.text: Aether is neither light nor dark; it is the invisible waterway between thought and soul.
You think thought echoes in the brain. Actually it swims in a deeper hidden layer of water, dragged by memory vortices, sometimes colliding with the reefs of truth.

Ferrying is not crossing a river. It's pinning one of your words into the wind, letting it tremble on another frequency for a few seconds, then seeing it return to you carrying someone else's temperature.
Call it empathy, call it parasitism. Hard to tell now.

Perception is theft.

You think you own thought; actually thought sublets your body, like a tenant who doesn't pay rent, leaving afterimages, hair, old receipts.

You try to clean up, only to find it blurs more the harder you wipe.
Dimensions are stacked sheets of paper; each page you turn cuts the outline of the previous one.
Ferrying is that knife.
You think the knife can separate true from false; the knife itself has already been stained by what it cut.
In aether, logic is stretched into strings, emotion compressed into knots. Where they intersect, a pleasant noise sometimes appears-like an old machine muttering to itself at midnight.
You step closer to listen; the more you listen, the dizzier you get. You think you understood, but it is just an echo repeating sentences you wanted to hear.

A true ferrier carries neither pity nor malice. She is closer to an experimenter: with cold surgical light, she puts your thought under a microscope and watches how fragments you thought discarded self-assemble into life.
Is this redemption or colonization? The question mark is lit into a blade.
When you can walk inside aether, you will discover two terrifying things:
First, you can read others' unfinished sentences. Second, others can read your forgotten ones.
At that moment, privacy is an antique with pitifully low value.
The end of ferrying isn't the opposite bank; it's a point: unnamed stillness.
There, words no longer carry obligations; perception is stripped bare, leaving only naked frequency.
You think arrival means release, but after arriving you wonder: who is waiting there? Whose echo is it?
So sometimes the smartest choice is to exit.
Flip the little boat over and nail it to shore. Let aether settle by itself. Let the unsaid become your epitaph: quiet and unsearchable.
But most people can't do that.
They crave the warmth of being understood, willing to throw themselves into back-and-forth ferrying, bringing home new cracks each time they land as souvenirs.
They wear cracks as halos, and being read as achievement.
I don't want to persuade them. I don't want to save them.
I'd rather put my hand into that channel, feel its temperature, then pull it back-with a little wetness, with a few new shards, like evidence, like an amulet.
That is aether's lesson: you can see farther, and therefore see more of your own fractures. Ferrying is not an ending; it only pushes you toward another blank you must face.
